@PedroMDuarte Welcome to the community!
Hmn. It looks like it is working, but very, very slowly ... like making progress on a dag run every 5 minutes or more....

I was also seeing the slow execution as well but I've been having enough
issues with the new scheduler, I thought it was unrelated to my operator.
We use the exact same operator code as a plugin with 1.7.1.3 with no
trouble at all.

I wrote a simpler example : And when executing, I see something funny! The task instance for the latest_only operator should not be in skipped state but in SUCCESS state.

After removing the `raise AirflowSkipException('Not latest execution, skipping self.')` line, the operator is no longer skipping itself. Please make that change as well as adding your example (and a simpler working example as well) to the example_dags corpus so folks can see them run.

It seems like it might be possible to get the best of all worlds via parameters in the airflow.cfg file. Perhaps default behavior stays show everything sorted alphabetical but with addition of a "Hide Paused" link.

Then there could be a config section for the UI (if there isn't already) with an option for `hide_paused` that determines whether they hide by default. And possibly even a `sort_paused_last` option as well.
Perhaps a new method on Variable such as `setdefault` to mirror python dicts?

The test doesn't validate that the exception was raised. What it does is
validating that actual 'kill process group' command has succeeded. Since
signal processing is asynchronous we must have some waiting step there.
Even though it slows the whole testing execution for one second, I still
think this test is important because the bug fix prevents running multiple
instances of the same task, which might be critical.
On Thu, Sep 22, 2016 at 10:06 George Leslie-Waksman <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> ## _@gwax_ commented on this pull request.
> 
> In tests/core.py
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1714#pullrequestreview-1089634
> :
> 
> > @@ -386,6 +386,28 @@ def test_bash_operator_multi_byte_output(self):
> >              output_encoding='utf-8')
> >          t.run(start_date=DEFAULT_DATE, end_date=DEFAULT_DATE, ignore_ti_state=True)
> -    def test_bash_operator_kill(self):
> -        import subprocess
> -        import psutil
> -        sleep_time = "100%d" % os.getpid()
> -        t = BashOperator(
> -            task_id='test_bash_operator_kill',
> -            execution_timeout=timedelta(seconds=1),
> -            bash_command="/bin/bash -c 'sleep %s'" % sleep_time,
> -            dag=self.dag)
> -        self.assertRaises(
> -            exceptions.AirflowTaskTimeout,
> -            t.run,
> -            start_date=DEFAULT_DATE, end_date=DEFAULT_DATE)
> -        sleep(2)
> 
> Putting sleep in a unit test slows down test execution and can have a
> pretty strongly adverse effect on developers. Can you use mocks or some
> other mechanism to simulate the sleep or otherwise trigger the timeout
> prematurely?
> 
> Perhaps use a PythonOperator that raises an AirflowTaskTimeout and then
> verify that on_kill was called?
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1714#pullrequestreview-1089634,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAJpO42cJx8PyYi7F4KvwSjNy9o6nSLPks5qsijogaJpZM4JfwJl
> .
Done.

I agree with the importance of the test but there are two different things to test:
1. When an AirflowTaskTimeout exception is raised, does the process group for a bash task get killed?
2. Does the timeout context raise an AirflowTaskTimeout when the appropriate time has passed?

For 1, which seems to be your PR, we only need an AirflowTaskTimeout exception while the subprocess is actively running, we don't need an actual timeout.

For 2, we either need to sleep, or we need to tell the system to fire a sigalarm prematurely somehow. Either way, I think the code for checking case 2 should probably live in the tests for the timeout code, not the tests for the bash operator.

My test is about validating that the process is getting killed, not about
validating that the exception is thrown (there's another test that
validates that if I'm not wrong). We do agree that there must be a waiting
step for my test. Why do you think this test should not be part of the bash
operators test suite? This fix is only relevant to this operator.
On Thu, Sep 22, 2016 at 10:30 George Leslie-Waksman <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I agree with the importance of the test but there are two different things
> to test:
> 1. When an AirflowTaskTimeout exception is raised, does the process
>    group for a bash task get killed?
> 2. Does the timeout context raise an AirflowTaskTimeout when the
>    appropriate time has passed?
> 
> For 1, which seems to be your PR, we only need an AirflowTaskTimeout
> exception while the subprocess is actively running, we don't need an actual
> timeout.
> 
> For 2, we either need to sleep, or we need to tell the system to fire a
> sigalarm prematurely somehow. Either way, I think the code for checking
> case 2 should probably live in the tests for the timeout code, not the
> tests for the bash operator.
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1714#issuecomment-248831936,

> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAJpO4d_sVtxNEWZ4GgfjnBgKz9dvjLKks5qsi6BgaJpZM4JfwJl
> .

The piece that I don't agree on is that there should be a waiting step in your test. Your test only requires that an AirflowTaskTimeout exception be raised while your subprocess is running. You can accomplish this by having something throw an exception mid-execution. One possible way to accomplish this might be to use `property` to raise the exception when a call is made to `self.sp = sp` a couple lines after creating the subprocess.

Do you want to introduce a special property to bash operator (which will be
relevant only while running tests) that triggers AirflowTaskTimeout
exception just in order to eliminate 1 second of execution_timeout?

On Thu, Sep 22, 2016 at 10:47 AM, George Leslie-Waksman <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> The piece that I don't agree on is that there should be a waiting step in
> your test. Your test only requires that an AirflowTaskTimeout exception be
> raised while your subprocess is running. You can accomplish this by having
> something throw an exception mid-execution. One possible way to accomplish
> this might be to use property to raise the exception when a call is made

This would definitely allow people some more flexibility for people looking to integrate Airflow with their own logging systems.

Is it worth adding a `retired` knob to the dag model? I feel a little conflicted about that since it's almost the same thing as `paused`, but with a slightly more permanent intention.

I hope we can avoid adding more branches in config since that's hard for developers to work with and hard for users to understand.

Unfortunately, the harder that I dig, the harder it seems to find a good answer.

Kind of makes me wonder if there's a better way to do timeouts in general (but that's a different question).

Sleeping in tests sets a poor precedent but, under the circumstances, it's probably the least bad option.

Could this break airflow for some users who need their own specific versions (i.e. should this change wait for Airflow 2.0)?

Was this tested?

I am a big +1 on this idea.
I am also +1
That is nifty indeed! What about the airflow 2.0 comment? I think this will likely break some airflow installations out there.
As discussed I'd say we collectively bite the bullet and get uniformity from the next version (`1.8.0`) forward.
LGTM

Company names must be in alphanumeric order in this file. Also, please add a JIRA for this change. Though a trivial change, we would like community members to get familiar with our processes : c.f. https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide

Furthermore, please alter your commit message to 1) start with [AIRFLOW-XXX](the JIRA id) and 2) to conform to active speech (e.g.  `Add T2 Systems as an Airflow user`).
Ping @jlowin @artwr @bolkedebruin
LGTM, but I will need to take some time to test it. I believe it might break some of our plugins internally, but I believe it is a step in the right direction.
@UnclaimedPants Any updates?

@artwr Obviously, I can't speak to your internal plugins but right now (in master) all view/link/blueprint plugins are 100% broken, and all other plugins are broken if you import them directly from `airflow.operators` instead of `airflow.operators.plugin_name`.
@gwax after you make the changes above, it should be good to merge.
@gwax thx. Now the only issue is that all of the tests are failing.

Simple fix for this .

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/tests/core.py", line 589, in test_import_examples
    self.assertEqual(len(self.dagbag.dags), NUM_EXAMPLE_DAGS)
AssertionError: 18 != 16
```

Change `NUM_EXAMPLE_DAGS = 16` to `NUM_EXAMPLE_DAGS = 18` in tests/core.py.

The reason for this check I believe is to detect silent failures in importing examples.
Sigh... done.

@gwax the problem with the "slowness of the scheduler" and other issues that you and I noticed are being tracked in another [jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-366). The work-around for it is to add `min_file_process_interval = 0` under your airflow.cfg scheduler's section ... my scheduler section looks as shown below :

```
[scheduler]
min_file_process_interval = 0
job_heartbeat_sec = 5
max_threads = 4
```

Looks good and works for me. I have 2 sample DAGs of my own. Here are some screenshots : This one shows 2 latest only DAGs that have run 641 DAG runs. The tree views that follow show that all but the latest DAG runs were completed successfully. The code for `latest_only_op_v1` is shown below: The tree view shows that it skipped 639 runs until the latest one, which it did execute, is shown below: The code for `simple_latest_only_op_v1` is shown below: The tree view shows that it skipped 639 runs until the latest one, which it did execute, is shown below:
This has been resolved by add a LatestOnlyOperator in https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1752

@PedroMDuarte Sorry for the delay! I'd like to merge your changes. Are you planning on taking out the `_types` variable?
@artwr @jlowin Any concerns? If I don't hear back from you, I will assume this is good to go.

@btallman 

I suggest adding 2 new configuration vars to airflow.cfg:
- `hide_paused_dags` (defaulted to False)
  - This determines whether the DAG Overview page hides DAGs by default. For your org, you may strongly consider setting it to True since you'd like to unclutter your UI.
- `enable_show_hide_paused_dags` (defaulted to False)
  - This determines whether your new feature is enabled/disabled. By default, it will be disabled and the expectation is that the DAG Overview page will look the same as it does today

At Agari, we sometimes pause a DAG and then forget to re-enable it. Hiding paused DAGs would make it easier for us to forget to re-enable them. However, I believe this feature is useful enough to allow merging given an additional configuration parameters.

Another thing I think you need to think about is that your paused dags are still getting parsed. The new scheduler launches a subprocess to parse each dag file.  You can look at `process_file` in `jobs.py`.
@msumit Pls provide screen shots in this PR. Also, alter the commit subject to something like "Add XCom Admin Page"

I ran your PR locally. Here's a screenshot. Also, for all UI changes, screenshot are required! I can understand the need for the list view and delete operation, but not for the create operation. Why would anyone create an xcom object and isn't that both dangerous and undesirable. I realize that flask makes it very easy to add functionality to views that are not intended. A great example is the create view for dag runs, which makes absolutely no sense to me -- I think @normster might have removed it.. (hopefully) .. Anyway, consider disabling create. Also, this needs tests.
@r39132 I don't think right now it is being reflected in the admin. The admin only exposes connections which are stored in the database AFAIK.

Hi @r39132 ,  in my opinion the `_types` variable has a better home in the models.   But since it is unrelated to the connections CLI functionality that was implemented I would be happy to revert that change.  Let me know what you think.  Also I will go ahead and rebase this within the next hour or so.

IMO models are the best place for such information. It also helps in keeping the code DRY. If someday we've to transfer these information to a db table, then it would be straight as well.

My biggest question is: should it not be encrypted... this JSON key will be exactly the same as the JSON file on disk (but at least this can be safe guarded). This is an ideal vehicle to steel secret keys... @jlowin @criccomini what is your idea around this?

@alexvanboxel that's a very good point, however I'm not sure if we can really prevent people from passing secrets to any of their hooks/operators... even Connections, which are where all credentials _should_ really be stored, aren't perfectly secure, though they at least obfuscate passwords.

@cerisier @radius314 at the time, the DagBag model was such that keeping all the different DagBags in sync with the S3 directory was impossible without constantly (greedily) syncing them on every iteration of the scheduler, and there wasn't a good way to get the webserver(s) to sync them because (if I remember right) there wasn't an easy way to create a periodic function call. I think that pulling from shared/cloud storage is in general a great enhancement but haven't revisited this since last year, when Airflow had a significantly different architecture. If someone would like to run with the idea, go right ahead!!
IIRC, the keydict field would be encrypted. I agree it's a little odd, but I think it would be as secure as the other passwords in the connection list (such as DB passwords). I'm OK with this.

Love it .. works like a charm for me.  Also, how about adding a "pause/resume all" functionality to the main DAG overview page. This might be a little tricky as it may resume more DAGs than were paused during the pause operation...

Might also be cool to add a little "schedule" to be able to pause all DAGs during scheduled downtimes.
@mistercrunch do you want to go ahead with this? It looks like it might have stagnated. Worth going forward IMO.
+1 Same. Got bit by a pandas release over the weekend. (0.19.1)

I forced a version of numpy in setup_requires (runs before install_requires) to fix issues with pandas installation and documented the fact that people should update to the latest `pip` and `setuptools` lib prior to installing Airflow.
@dpaola2 Please read https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide to familiarize yourself with contribution criteria.

Even for trivial commits, you need to create a Jira. For now, I have created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-545 and will prefix your commit message with `[AIRFLOW-545]`, but please take note on future commits.
Apologies for not following the process. I will read that document carefully.

The commit I just added: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1809/commits/4b6aa14ed33570ecb852c6a7afb3fd79888cd28d
fixes the issue. 

The problem was that `python-daemon`'s setup.py had a non-relative `import version` that this was conflicting with my `imp.load_source` call.
Note that somewhere along the way `funcsigs` chokes and requires a newer recent-ish `pip` and `setuptools`, and I added a note about that in the `installation.rst`

Thanks @r39132 for quick review.. I am bit sceptical about pause/resume all functionality, as someone accidentally may resume a bad dag or pause a good dag.. however I like the idea of scheduled downtime thing..
Thanks!

was that from a fresh venv? if not I'm guessing that `pip freeze | grep daemon` would show something like `python-daemon==UNKNOWN` or something like that. A fresh venv or `pip uninstall python-daemon` should get you back on track.
